items.title: Enable Proxies for Token Acquisition in `iControlRESTTokenAuth`
items.body:
As of #169 "Allow proxies kwarg from sdk ManagementRoot", the `proxies` attribute is pushed all the way down into the `iControlRESTSession` object and [applied to the underlying `requests.Session` object](https://github.com/F5Networks/f5-icontrol-rest-python/blob/1.0/icontrol/session.py#L427).

However, there remains a problem with token acquisition in `iControlRESTTokenAuth` as it appears to still utilize plain `requests.<verb>` calls and does not have access to the outer session or it's proxy configuration.

Example in `iControlRESTTokenAuth.get_new_token()`:
https://github.com/F5Networks/f5-icontrol-rest-python/blob/1.0/icontrol/authtoken.py#L146

Example in `iControlRESTTokenAuth.get_auth_providers()`:
https://github.com/F5Networks/f5-icontrol-rest-python/blob/1.0/icontrol/authtoken.py#L98

This results in a condition where a user is unable to actually utilize the outer proxy-enabled session object, because the acquisition of a token is not proxy-enabled.

---

In my testing, simply passing the `proxies` dict down into `iControlRESTTokenAuth` upon initialization, and then further passing it to the above example `Requests` calls as an additional attribute on the request itself seems to work.

I am happy to open a PR with an attempted fix, just wanted to raise the issue first.

items.title: subPath should allow for "/" and translate it appropriately to "~"
items.body:
This issue discovered and reported on the sdk repo: https://github.com/F5Networks/f5-common-python/issues/1522.

For gtm members reference, unable to properly use subPath to check exists. If I have a subPath of **ltm3.test.local:/part1** on my member object and submit the query:

gp.members_s.member.exists(name='v1', subPath='ltm3.test.local:/part1', partition='Common')

I get this error:

```
  File "/Users/rahm/Documents/PycharmProjects/f5-common-python/f5py3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/icontrol/session.py", line 212, in generate_bigip_uri
    **kwargs)
  File "/Users/rahm/Documents/PycharmProjects/f5-common-python/f5py3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/icontrol/session.py", line 181, in _validate_uri_parts
    _validate_name_partition_subpath(sub_path)
  File "/Users/rahm/Documents/PycharmProjects/f5-common-python/f5py3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/icontrol/session.py", line 150, in _validate_name_partition_subpath
    raise InvalidInstanceNameOrFolder(error_message)
icontrol.exceptions.InvalidInstanceNameOrFolder: instance names and partitions cannot contain '/', but it's: ltm3.test.local:/part1
```

If I [comment out the validation](https://github.com/F5Networks/f5-icontrol-rest-python/blob/1.0/icontrol/session.py#L184), I still get a 400 error from the rest interface because it does not like the "/" supplied in the subPath.

But if I change my subPath from **ltm3.test.local:/part1** to **ltm3.test.local:~part1**, I get a successful response.

So I think what we need to do is twofold:

- Allow "/" to be submitted in a subPath kwarg
- Translate that "/" to a "~" before finalizing the url

items.title: v1.3.5 release compat with python3.4
items.body:
Hello,

since the last v1.3.5 release, we have issues using the lib with python3.4
```
lib/python3.4/site-packages/f5/bigip/resource.py:1002: in create
return self._create(**kwargs)
lib/python3.4/site-packages/f5/bigip/resource.py:968: in _create
response = session.post(_create_uri, json=kwargs, **requests_params)
lib/python3.4/site-packages/icontrol/session.py:263: in wrapper
response = method(self, REST_uri, **kwargs)
lib/python3.4/site-packages/icontrol/session.py:541: in post
self._debug.append(debug_prepared_request(prepared))
lib/python3.4/site-packages/icontrol/session.py:614: in debug_prepared_request
kwargs = json.loads(request.body)

E TypeError: the JSON object must be str, not 'bytes'
```
Thanks,

items.title: SSL verification disabled, without option to enable
items.body:
On debian stretch I get warnings:
`/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py:852: InsecureRequestWarning: Unverified HTTPS request is being made. Adding certificate verification is strongly advised. See: https://urllib3.readthedocs.io/en/latest/advanced-usage.html#ssl-warnings
  InsecureRequestWarning)
`
I found at https://github.com/F5Networks/f5-icontrol-rest-python/blob/1.0/icontrol/authtoken.py#L98
the request is made with verify=False. It would be nice to be able to change this setting through F5 libraries to be able to verify ssl.
Anyway thank you for great work to make icontrol available from python.

items.title: Loading a client SSL profile that belongs to an app
items.body:
I'm trying to load a client SSL profile, but I get an exception because the profile belongs to an app (the reason is that the path contains slashes): 

icontrol.exceptions.InvalidInstanceNameOrFolder: instance names and partitions **cannot contain '/'**, but it's: /Common/xxx.yyy.app/

I've tested this with a profile that doesn't belong to an app (partition 'Common') and it works.
csslp = mgmt.tm.ltm.profile.client_ssls.client_ssl.load(name=profilename, partition=partitionname)

Can someone confirm that this is an issue?

items.title: Update the User-Agent to include library and version
items.body:
Add the library and version to the user agent header that is sent to the BIG-IP so that it can be logged to track usage and help debug problems.  This needs to be done in a way that allows users of this library to add additional strings to the end of the header.

The user agent string should be `f5-icontrol-rest-python/<version>`

items.title: Requests should be able to specify the subPath in addition to partition and name
items.body: In order to service the issue https://github.com/F5Networks/f5-common-python/issues/468, the icontrolsession needs to be able to support a subPath keyword argument to requests. This allows a consumer to get access to an object created in an iapp or an object in the drafts folder (in BIG-IP 12.1).

items.title: Requests version needs to be 2.5.0 or greater from this repo
items.body:
If a user is starting with a lower version of requests than 2.5.0, they will see failures coming from this module (when attempting to disable the warning messages). We need to set the requests version >= 2.5.0. Otherwise folks get an error:

```
        if StrictVersion(requests_version) < '2.9.1':
            requests.packages.urllib3.disable_warnings()

        AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'packages'
```

Cheers,
@hh

items.title: We need to update the version of this library
items.body:
@swormke
The new version incorporates 2 modes of operation which are toggled with with the boolean `uri_as_parts`, the new version is required by f5-common-python for it's development branch to work correctly!

We need to update the version of this library, but I don't know (for certain) what our versioning convention is.    There is a related issue in f5-common-python that says we need to update its `requirements.txt` to require this new (not yet numbered) version:

https://github.com/F5Networks/f5-common-python/issues/105

items.title: Deactivation of urllib3 warnings does not work for requests 2.2.1 but it _does_ for requests 2.9.1
items.body:
How should we handle this versioning issue?   As a workaround in my local dev environment I set:
`requests >= 2.9.1` in requirements.txt.

items.title: The consumer of the library should never assumble uri's directly...  but how requests are submitted depends on "starting" uri.
items.body:
Assembling a uri from its parts should always be handled by the logic in the iCRS class...  but it's often the case that the caller already has a fully assembled valid uri for a device resource.

It's a bad idea to disassemble a valid uri just to pass it to this class to be reassembled _into the same thing_!

So, I've introduced 2 modes of operation for these two common use cases:

`uri_as_parts` is a boolean, which defaults to `False`.

If `uri_as_parts` is `False` then the iCRS object simply logs the pre-and-post request state, and raises iCRS specific exceptions for HTTP error codes.

If `uri_as_parts` is `True` then the iCRS object validates each part, and assembles the parts into a valid uri, in _addition_ to performing the above checks.

I can't close this issue until I add unittests of the `uri_as_parts` is `False` path, but as you can see by reading the above, that path is just a shortcut that follows the same route as the longer `uri_as_parts` is `True` path.

NOTE:   I think we _should_ support both modes, as they handle two different necessary use-cases.

I'm assigning @swormke because I need architectural input for this change.

I need to make some edits to CONTRIBUTING.md. 
For example:
"By filing meaningful bug reports will lots of information in them helps us figure out what to fix when and how it impacts our users. We like bugs because it means people are using our code, and we like fixing them even more."

items.title: Add a .git ignore file to the project
API documentation is available publicly
items.body: We need to make sure that the API documentation that is enabled by issue #18 is available publicly.  @jputrino should have a strategy for this that we need to enable and get working for this repository.

items.title: Requests.Session method calls were invoked with positional parameters.
items.body:
In principle this shouldn't matter, i.e. it should just work, but it's clearer to readers if the calls are invoked with keyword args.
It's also the case that this change makes the iControlRESTSession class robust to the unlikely event that parameter order changes in the requests.Session api.

items.title: Add package to the public PyPi repository
items.body: Once we have legal approval for the  meta files we can post the release on the public PyPi server.  This should be done for **release builds** only and should be done via our build/ci system.

items.title: Final versions of F5 approved README, CONTRIBUTING, SUPPORT and TERMS_OF_USE files
items.body: Once we have final approval of the required files for the meta files for the project we need to ensure that we have them in place and correct.  This must be done prior to opening the repository to the public.

items.title: Requests library is not included in the requirements
items.body:
The `requests` library is not included as a requirement for this library so after pip install if you want to try to use it you will get an error because requests is not found.

``` python
>>> from icontrol.session import iControlRESTSession
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "icontrol/session.py", line 18, in <module>
    import requests
ImportError: No module named requests
>>>
```

items.title: Update the README.md file to include the required sections for the project
items.body: The [README](README.md) file is missing most of the required sections for the project.  You can refer to the [README in f5-common-python](https://github.com/F5Networks/f5-common-python/blob/develop/README.md) as an example.

items.title: Explicitly set default assumptions for requests library
items.body: I _think_ there was a change in a newer version of requests that flipped the default setting of "allow_redirects" from True to False.  Need to make sure our library explicitly sets the things to match our requirements for interacting with BIGIP.

items.title: Each package/module/class/method must be fully documented.
The "suffix" keyword arg was not properly removed from the params dict, before it was passed to the requests.Session methods
items.body: Fixed by #15

items.title: Calls the requests.Session classes methods improperly pass "None"
items.body: Fixed by PR #15

items.title: Add structure and packaging for PyPi
items.body: Need to add makefiles, project packaging and project documentation

items.title: The BigIP REST Server Interface Supports Nested Folders
items.body:
Therefore (obviously) the [iControlRESTSession](https://github.com/F5Networks/f5-icontrol-rest-python/blob/develop/icontrol/session.py#L23) class must support nested folders.

For a complete design it'd be nice to get your @jgruber input.

items.title: The base_uri is properly and uniquely specified in the concrete subclass of RESTInterfaceCollection
items.body: This simplifies the `iControlRESTSession` class significantly since it is no longer responsible for composing the base_uri from the `bigip.icr_uri` and the `RESTInterfaceCollection` (concrete subclass) specific path fragment string.  That is now the responsibility of the concrete subclasses, **init** method.

items.title: BigIP Server Specific State Should be Compiled and Used in the BigIP Class.
items.body: This can/should be used (e.g. with a strict mode) to handle requests against non-existant resources, and more generally to handle errors caused by changes in the version.

items.title: What's the right location for the iControlRESTSession logs?
items.body: Once we figure it out, we need to do the right thing.

items.title: How does a real BigIP a handle a missing folder-or-instance_name, we should do the right thing once we learn this.
Each BigIP Object That is being managed via icontrol, should have a REST session object
